summary: The document provides an overview of the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board (PFIAB) meetings held on June 25-26, 1963, detailing discussions on various intelligence activities. These include CIA operations, State Department intelligence, signals intelligence (SIGINT), and covert actions. Notable topics include the OXCART incident, intelligence efforts concerning Cuba, the quality of U-2 photography over Cuba, and discussions on the Profumo case in Britain and the Penkovskiy espionage case in the USSR. The document underscores concerns regarding intelligence security and the issue of leaks.
key_findings: The PFIAB evaluated its contributions over the past two years and explored ways to enhance its utility to the President.
The OXCART incident was discussed, with a focus on the crash and subsequent security measures.
Intelligence operations targeting Cuba were a major topic, including strategies to incite disaffection among Cuban military personnel and sabotage efforts.
Challenges related to U-2 photography over Cuba, particularly due to adverse weather conditions, were noted.
The Profumo case in Britain and the Penkovskiy espionage case in the USSR were examined, raising concerns about intelligence security.
The document highlights the absence of a specialized investigative team to tackle intelligence leaks and unauthorized disclosures.
